Topic.Title: Anandtech: Tegra 4 architecture deep dive & etc

Message.Msg: The core may be the same, the final implmentation on the SOC is absolutely different and so is the 28nm process technology. There are many flavors of 28nm technology even at TSMC. For Samsung 28nm - they have multiple 28nm process problems - a big part of it is - it's not stable and can be a contributing factor to excessive leaky transistors. Their 28nm process may not have a good leakage vs performance characteristics to start with. And the Exyhosed 5 certainly have a lot more transistors and die area then T4 making the power situation worse. Besides the power scheme of the T4 is a 2nd generation and appears a lot more effective than E5. So E5 mwith a dumb down GPU may appear in a tablet instead.

Topic.Title: Why Get Your Specs From The Tech Press When You Can Go To The Source!

Message.Msg: Idon't know. I guess I'm kinda old school. I can go to Ti's website and get specs, package sizes, data sheets. Same with Intel and AMD especially back in the days of the benchmark wars. Microchip, Atmel, On Semi everythinbg is available on the website. Same with Nvidia but when I go the Qualcomm website all I can find is the S600 doesn't have a modem and the S800 when it arrives will have an integrated modem. Plus I can't find datasheets or package sizes for any Qualcomm part. Perhaps only customers get that info. Strange if the Chief Marketing Officer says "Snapdragon cleans Tegra 4 clock". I would have thought he have all the data in the world up on the website to prove it. But that's just me.

Topic.Title: Anandtech: Tegra 4 architecture deep dive & etc

Message.Msg: Nvidia is HIDING the power characteristics, while touting performance. Enough said. Tegra4 is a Powerhog. Different 28nm processes make some difference but not a lot.

Topic.Title: Why Get Your Specs From The Tech Press When You Can Go To The Source!

Message.Msg: Also, I remember that Old Timer Steve Jobs - showing benchmarks at Apple events and every new edition of Apple devices shows relative performance to the last iteration. Just old school I guess.

Topic.Title: Anandtech: Tegra 4 architecture deep dive & etc

Message.Msg: 20% less power than Tegra 3 while streaming a 1080p video I thought. Where are you getting the idea that Tegra 4 is a powerhog?

Topic.Title: Anandtech: Tegra 4 architecture deep dive & etc

Message.Msg: 28nm processes MAKES ALL the difference - Samsung has not shipped a single 28nm product - their process is not proven and it's leaky. For that reason Apple may be in trouble too if they are counting on 28nm from Samsung for their next AP!

Message.Title: Benchmarks are in: NVIDIA's Tegra 4 really cooks
Message.Msg: When Nvida announced the Tegra 4 back at CES, they laid down the claim it was the world's fastest mobile processor. Now Nvidia's got some prototype devices at Mobile World Congress, the benchmarks are coming in and there's no questioning it. The Tegra 4 is a total speed-demon. A generation better than the Tegra 3 and Qualcomm S4 processors common now, it shouldn't be a surprise that the Tegra 4 can demolish the processor in just about every other phone on the market, but now the proof is in. And Apple's peppy A6 is no exclusion. Then again, the Tegra 4's got a bit of a head start. SOURCE: gizmodoDOTcom/5986554/benchmarks-are-in-nvidias-tegra-4-really-cooks

Topic.Title: Anandtech: Tegra 4 architecture deep dive & etc

Message.Msg: The part currently produced as "Exynos 5" has two A15 cores, not four. The announced "octo-core" part will have four A15+A7 paired cores. This is apparently an integrated set that ARM licenses as a pair. That suggests that they may be tightly coupled in hardware, rather than two very different CPU cores merely adjacent on the die. My guess is that this part will be marketed under a new name to distinguish it from the existing Exynos 5.

Topic.Title: Speculation: PS4 Streaming

Message.Msg: And now this AM we see announcements about AMD's answer to NVDA grid. No idea how it'll compete, but the "FirePro R5000 Remote Graphics Card for Deployment in Data Centers" seems to be their answer. here's a blurb from the AMD press release, quoting an adopter of the previous generation product, which the R5000 is supposedly 4x as powerful as: "Tasked with finding a thin client solution capable accelerating real-time 2D and basic 3D graphics for game development and computer animation classes, we turned to AMD's first generation remote graphics product, the ATI FirePro™ RG220," said Mahesh Neelakanta, director of the Technical Services Group, Florida Atlantic University. "Not only were we able to conserve energy and save time on system maintenance, the graphics cards were able to handle video, 2D images and animations, and 3D elements without bogging down the system or noticeable pixelation. Offering a more powerful GPU, four times the memory and nearly eight times the memory bandwidth of the RG220, the R5000 will allow us to deploy remote systems for our more advanced classes and configure multimonitor set ups our students will eventually encounter in the workplace." ___ Again, I have no idea if this is actually competitive with NVDA Grid in performance, but it seems safe assume this product, or some closely-related variant, is being pitched to Sony to go along with the AMD GPU/CPUs in the upcoming PS4s.

Topic.Title: Tegra 4i SoC is also built on TSMC's 28 HPM process

Message.Msg: Im with you. I just don't see the appeal of QCOM anymore, seeing as how NVDA can (or will be able to in a short time) match QCOM in pretty much every aspect of mobile. Granted, QCOM may be able to undercut NVDA on price, which means alot, after the benchmarks were released on Tegra 4, and by most accounts, T4i will also out-perform Snapdragon, I cant understand why we aren't seeing more wins for NVDA. Long term, I think NVDA is in a much better position for growth than QCOM, with T4, T4i, Shield, Grid, and eventually Denver. I'm sitting on roughly 10K shares, so I'm content on collecting the dividend while I wait for positive movement. In all, I think NVDA is a good long term investment with groth opportunity, decent dividend, and a robust buy back program. Good luck to all longs.

Topic.Title: Speculation: PS4 Streaming

Message.Msg: "However, it kept quiet about comparing it against technology from rival Nvidia, which launched its VGX platform for accelerating graphics in the cloud last year. AMD's FirePro is restricted to a one-to-one relationship, meaning it is tied to accelerating the graphics output from a single physical or virtual workstation, while Nvidia's platform enables the GPU resources to be sliced up so it can accelerate the graphics for multiple virtual machines." FROM LINK "The first Nvidia VGX board design is configured with four of the new Kepler GPUs, each with 192 Nvidia ________________________________________________________________________________ Doesn't look even remotely comparable....to Nvidia's VGX and neither is for Cloud gaming. That's the Nvidia Grid. CUDA architecture cores, plus 16GB of memory. It is claimed to be capable of supporting up to 100 virtual desktop users, according to the firm."

Topic.Title: T4 and Q800 were both introduced at the same time

Message.Msg: ZTE Grand Memo hands-on: a first look at Qualcomm's Snapdragon 800 in action (video) Mobile By Joseph Volpe posted Feb 25th, 2013 at 11:33 AM ZTE caught us by surprise today, outing a Snapdragon 800-infused version of the Grand Memo at its MWC 2013 presser. The device, which still features the same 5.7-inch 720p display, 13-megapixel rear camera and 3,200mAh battery, is nearly indistinguishable from the other variants we've seen. But for this go-round, ZTE's added in Dolby Digital Plus Surround for a superior audio experience and an extra GB of RAM. Its external chassis may have remained the same -- plasticky and lightweight -- but the difference in this 8.9mm thick Memo's real-world performance is immediately noticeable. OS actions on the skinned Jelly Bean UI don't just zip, they now quite literally fly -- truly, this device is deserving of the long-deceased "beast" moniker. Although international tradeshow WiFi connections are typically dreadful, we did manage to successfully run the Sunspider benchmark to get a quick taste of its rendering performance. The result? The Grand Memo notched a score of 1,186.7ms -- an unimpressive result when contrasted with the Tegra 4's 499ms (as derived from a reference tablet). As for ZTE's MyFavorite UX layered atop Android 4.1.2, well, we're pleased to say it yields some neat animations. The entire homescreen, including widgets, revolves with a smooth 3D effect that just imbues the handset with a special "feel." It's a shame then that the Memo's encased in a less than premium shell, as it creates a disconnect between the smoking internals and humdrum exterior. But with a newly announced commitment to building its brand (a sentiment popular with Chinese OEMs as of late), this particular Memo is proof positive that ZTE's serious about raising its profile and consumer perception. You won't be seeing this Grand Memo hit US shores anytime soon -- it's a China and Europe-only affair for now. So while you wait (and hold onto hope), check out our video tour after the break.

Topic.Title: The market could care less about T4 benchmarks...

Message.Msg: Tech markets don't usually case much about $$$ in the short term. In the short term, good benchmarks are helpful because they speak to the likelihood of future design wins. Design wins are even more helpful, because they speak of future $$$. These benches are good because they dismiss at least part of the rumor mill that said NVDA chips were underperformers. Being an underdog with underperforming chips is hopeless. Being an underdog with great chips is something that you can build on. For stock pickers, it is something that you can speculate on.
